Award.AwardTitle: Conference on Current Progress in Mathematical Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for participation in the conference "Current Progress in Mathematical Physics" to be held at Harvard University in Boston, MA over the course of four days during the week of December 10--17, 2018. The conference will focus on recent developments in analysis, especially in the field of mathematical physics and quantum information science. The goal of the meeting is to bring together a broad spectrum of mathematicians, physicists, and information scientists to cross-fertilize ongoing research, stimulate new collaborations, and discuss long-range research goals. The interdisciplinary structure aims to interest students and researchers in potential new methods and to advance ideas that cross the boundaries of mathematics, physics, and quantum information.

The conference will feature presentations by leading researchers in mathematical physics and quantum information science. One topical focus is a recently-discovered coincidence between representation theory and Riemannian geometry and its potential use in development of a consistent mathematical theory that embodies both quantum theory and relativity. Other topics emphasized in the conference include geometrical concepts in quantum information theory and the development of an analytic point of view in topological quantum field theory. This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, and researchers without other sources of support an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference. More information will be made available at the conference webpage: http://www.arthurjaffe.com/Assets/pdf/HarvardWorkshop.pdf

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We held a conference at Harvard University on December 10—12, 2018, with 20 scientific talks, of which 2 were given by women and 7 were given by junior researchers, two of whom are current students with interesting new results.  The schedule of speakers was:

Monday: 
9:05 James Glimm
10:30 Vaughan Jones
11:30 Giovanni Felder

14:00 Edward Witten 
15:20 Zhengwei Liu 
16:20 Cumrun Vafa 

 

Tuesday:
9:00 David Evans
10:20 Anke Pohl 

13:00 Jennifer Chayes 
14:20 Shamil Shakirov 
15:20 Christoph Schweigert 

 

Wednesday:
9:00 Klaus Hepp
10:20 Xiao-Gang Wen
11:20 Mikhail Lukin

14:00 Christian J?kel 
14:30 Bas Janssens 
15:00 Davis Lazowski 
15:40 William Norledge 
16:10 Yunxiang Ren 
16:40 Michele Tienni 

The coffee breaks and meal breaks led to very interesting interactions and discussions. The talks ranged from interesting review talks to exciting insights into not-yet published work. A highlight of the first type was the very wide-ranging review by James Glimm of how scaling and renormalization ideas can be used in fields ranging from quantum field theory to classical hydrodynamics. A highlight of the second type was the talk by Zhengwei Liu which introduced a new way to understand error correction in quantum computation through the study of quon language graphs. This language, introduced by Jaffe, Liu, and Wozniakowski in 2017 has opened up several interesting new avenues of research in quantum information. Current work related to quantum error correction has revealed many exciting new research paths to explore, and it has become the focus of a large collaborative project to implement these ideas in the laboratory.. Aside from these two talks, one could say that almost every talk was inspiring.

Addendum # 1

Revised Summary Report from Arthur Jaffe

NSF grant DMS-1836744

 

The original document submitted was a summary of all conference costs from multiple sources, and included other costs not supported by the NSF grant DMS-1836744. We apologize for this error.

 

The 5 participants in the original report (Alina Vdovina, Lisa Carbone, William Norledge, Jinsong Wu and Bas Janssens) are all non-Harvard participants whose travel or local lodging costs were supported by the grant. An additional 10 other non-Harvard participants whose travel costs or lodging were supported by the NSF grant are: Anke Pohl, Vaughan Jones, Palle Jorgensen, Edward Witten, John Ewing, Thomas Spencer, Alberto Cattaneo, Jon Dimock, Gordon Ritter, and Christian Wieczerkowski. We were able to pay for an average 4 night stay in Cambridge hotels or bed and breakfasts for a total of 21 non-Harvard participants with the grant funds.

 

There was a total of $2,364 spent on food costs during the conference of the $3,000 budgeted. This was for coffee, fruit and pastries each morning during the 3-day conference, for food for an opening reception, and for coffee breaks during the conference’s three-day program.

 

There were 16 young researchers at the conference, many of whom were Harvard undergraduate students, graduate students and researchers. In addition there were 4 or 5 young researchers who were non-Harvard participants.
